entry.et: Middle English capitale, from Anglo-French capital, capitel, from Late Latin capitellum small head, top of column, diminutive of Latin capit-, caput head head

def.dt: :the uppermost member of a column or pilaster crowning the shaft and taking the weight of the entablature see column illustration

entry.et: Middle English, from Latin capitalis, from capit-, caput (see capital)

def.dt: :of or conforming to the series A, B, C, etc. rather than a, b, c, etc.
:punishable by death a capital crime
:involving execution capital punishment
:most serious a capital error
:chief in importance or influence capital ships the capital importance of criticism in the work of creation itself T. S. Eliot
:being the seat of government
:of or relating to capital (see capital)
:relating to or being assets that add to the long-term net worth of a corporation capital improvements
:excellent a capital book

dt.un: used with a following capital letter to emphasize or qualify a preceding word not an accident but murder with a capital M desired romance with a capital R

entry.et: French or Italian; French, from Italian capitale, from capitale, adjective, chief, principal, from Latin capitalis (see capital)

def.dt: :a stock of accumulated goods especially at a specified time and in contrast to income received during a specified period
:the value of these accumulated goods
:accumulated goods devoted to the production of other goods
:accumulated possessions calculated to bring in income
:net worth
:stock 7c(1)
:persons holding capital :capitalists considered as a group
:advantage gain make capital of the situation
:a store of useful assets or advantages wasted their political capital on an unpopular cause wrote from the capital of his emotionally desolate boyhood E. L. Doctorow
:a letter that conforms to the series A, B, C, etc. rather than a, b, c, etc. :a capital letter
:an initial capital letter
:a letter belonging to a style of alphabet modeled on the style customarily used in inscriptions
:a city serving as a seat of government
:a city preeminent in some special activity the fashion capital
:the increase in value of an asset (as stock or real estate) between the time it is bought and the time it is sold
:capital 1a(1) 1a(2)
:having a high capital cost per unit of output
:requiring greater expenditure in the form of capital than of labor
:the outstanding shares of a joint-stock company considered as an aggregate
:capitalization 1d
:stock 7c(1)
:capital (as stock or surplus earnings) that is free of debt
:capital received for an interest in the ownership of a business
:venture capital
:a letter having the form of but smaller than a capital letter (as in these words) called also small cap
